BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: At intermediate and high altitudes and on very steep slopes the situation is very dangerous. Avalanches can occur in particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place. Exposed parts of transportation routes can be endangered occasionally in particular in the regions with a lot of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 80 to 160 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m.
The large quantity of fresh snow of the weekend as well as the sometimes large wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released naturally in all altitude zones. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more dry and moist avalanches are possible, even quite large ones, especially on sunny slopes, as well as in steep rocky terrain.
The avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released.

The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects in all altitude zones. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of heavy snowfall and the moderate to strong wind, the snowpack could not consolidate during the last few days. New snow is lying on soft layers. This snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places. As a consequence of snowfall and the occasionally strong southerly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size at the weekend. In its middle, the snowpack is moist.
Monday: The weather conditions will facilitate a stabilisation of the near-surface layers towards the evening in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The natural avalanche activity will appreciably decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From starting zones at higher altitudes very large natural avalanches, capable of reaching the valleys, must be expected. Without question, it is inadvisable to engage in snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Numerous large and, in isolated cases, very large dry and wet avalanches have been released on Sunday. As a consequence of, heavy snowfall and the occasionally strong southeasterly wind, a very critical avalanche situation developed.
The snowpack will become unstable over a wide area. In localities where more snow falls danger level 5 (very high) may be reached in the late morning.
Many large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are further possible, also in all aspects on steep slopes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation dry and moist avalanches are possible, especially on sunny slopes, as well as in steep rocky terrain.
Exposed transportation routes and exposed settlements can be endangered in some localities.
The avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 100 to 160 cm of snow will fall until Monday above approximately 1800 m.
The southeasterly wind has transported a lot of snow. In all aspects large wind slabs formed.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. New snow is lying on soft layers. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered; its surface consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually. The new snow of the weekend remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. The conditions are sometimes precarious for snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: At intermediate and high altitudes and on very steep slopes the situation is very dangerous. Avalanches can occur in particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
60 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2000 m.
The large quantity of fresh snow of the weekend as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall can be released naturally in all altitude zones. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more dry and moist avalanches are possible, even quite large ones, especially on sunny slopes, as well as in steep rocky terrain.
The avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.

Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of snowfall and the occasionally strong southerly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size at the weekend.
New snow is lying on soft layers. This snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places. In some places new snow is lying on a moist old snowpack.
Monday: The weather conditions will facilitate a stabilisation of the near-surface layers towards the evening in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will facilitate a stabilisation of the near-surface layers as the day progresses in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. The avalanche danger will decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: At intermediate and high altitudes and on very steep slopes the situation is very dangerous. Avalanches can occur in particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 100 to 160 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more dry and moist avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases, especially on sunny slopes, as well as in steep rocky terrain. The avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released.

The large quantity of fresh snow and the large wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects and in all altitude zones.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for great caution and restraint. The avalanche danger will decrease during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Monday: As a consequence of heavy snowfall and the moderate to strong wind, the snowpack could not consolidate during the last few days. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places. As a consequence of snowfall and the occasionally strong southerly wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size at the weekend. The weather conditions will facilitate a stabilisation of the near-surface layers towards the evening in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The natural avalanche activity will appreciably decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. The current avalanche situation calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line.
The wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.

As a consequence of new snow and wind avalanches are to be expected, even large ones in isolated cases. The snowpack will be prone to triggering in particular in extremely steep terrain. The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday. The moderate wind has transported the old snow.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and has a loosely bonded surface.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will facilitate a stabilisation of the near-surface layers as the day progresses in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From starting zones at higher altitudes natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way, must be expected in many places. It is inadvisable to engage in snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, heavy snowfall the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation developed. Numerous medium-sized and large natural avalanches are possible. The snowpack will become unstable over a wide area.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation dry and moist avalanches are to be expected, especially on sunny slopes, as well as in steep rocky terrain.
Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on northwest, north and east facing slopes. Weak layers near the ground can be released by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 70 to 130 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Monday above approximately 1800 m.
The southeasterly wind has transported a lot of snow. In all aspects large wind slabs formed. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack in many places. New snow is lying on soft layers.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered; its surface consists of faceted crystals. Stability tests and field observations confirm a precarious avalanche situation.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually. The new snow of the weekend remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. The conditions are sometimes precarious for snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow on northwest, north and east facing slopes. Backcountry touring calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, snowfall above approximately 1600 m and the moderate to strong southeasterly wind, a precarious avalanche situation developed. The snowpack will be prone to triggering in particular in extremely steep terrain. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible.
In particular from starting zones at higher altitudes natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected in isolated cases.
Weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on northwest, north and east facing slopes. Weak layers near the ground can be released by individual winter sport participants. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.
The avalanche prone locations are widespread barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. In particular transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack where weaknesses exist in the old snowpack are precarious.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Monday above approximately 1500 m.
30 to 50 cm of snow fell in the last seven days above approximately 2000 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the new snow.
Towards its base, the snowpack is unfavourably layered; its surface consists of faceted crystals. Stability tests and field observations confirm a precarious avalanche situation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the snowfall slab avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be unstable in particular on steep northeast, north and northwest facing slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution. Wet loose snow avalanches are possible in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow of the weekend and the often large wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep west and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found also on very steep north facing slopes above approximately 2100 m. Avalanches can in isolated cases penetrate deep layers and reach large size.

As a consequence of the moist air wet loose snow avalanches are possible in the afternoon, even medium-sized ones. This applies in case of a single winter sport participant, especially on extremely steep sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.
In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last two days above approximately 1500 m. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack will soften quickly.

As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the wind slabs have increased in size. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. They are in some cases prone to triggering. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes. In very isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The weather conditions gave rise to softening of the snowpack.
Over a wide area precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large moist and wet avalanches are possible. In steep rocky terrain and adjacent to ridgelines more moist and wet snow slides are possible. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
Even single winter sport participants can release avalanches. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The snowpack remains generally moist. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be clear at times.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution. Wet loose snow avalanches are possible in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow of the weekend and the often large wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep west and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found also on very steep north facing slopes above approximately 2100 m. Avalanches can in isolated cases penetrate deep layers and reach large size.

As a consequence of the moist air wet loose snow avalanches are possible in the afternoon, even medium-sized ones. This applies in case of a single winter sport participant, especially on extremely steep sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.
In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last two days above approximately 1500 m. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. The surface of the snowpack will soften quickly.

As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the wind slabs have increased in size. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. They are in some cases prone to triggering. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes. In very isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The weather conditions gave rise to softening of the snowpack.
Over a wide area precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large moist and wet avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches can also occur at any time. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches as before.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular in the north a lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The snowpack remains generally moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be clear at times.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be barely evident. The surface of the snowpack is not frozen and will already be soft in the early morning. Already in the early morning, individual, then as a consequence of the rain more, and in some cases even medium-sized, wet and gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of high temperatures and rain the snowpack could settle hardly at all.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding avalanches are the main danger. Fresh wind slabs at high altitude. Wet loose snow avalanches are possible especially in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
An appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.

As a consequence of the moist air wet loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. This applies in case of a single winter sport participant, especially on extremely steep slopes below approximately 2400 m.

The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep east and west facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found also on very steep north facing slopes above approximately 2100 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. The snowpack will be wet all the way through below approximately 2200 m. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m.

Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. This applies above approximately 2600 m. In very isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gliding avalanches are the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding avalanches are the main danger. Fresh wind slabs at high altitude. Wet loose snow avalanches are possible especially in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
An appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach dangerously large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.

As a consequence of the moist air wet loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. This applies in case of a single winter sport participant, especially on extremely steep slopes below approximately 2400 m.

The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies especially adjacent to ridgelines. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep east and west facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found also on very steep north facing slopes above approximately 2100 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. The snowpack will be wet all the way through below approximately 2200 m. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m.

Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes. This applies above approximately 2600 m. In very isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gliding avalanches are the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In some localities some new snow. Wet and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
The new snow and wind slabs of Monday can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in all aspects above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some regions 5 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Monday above approximately 1600 m. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2200 m. The snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: New snow above approximately 1700 m. In some localities up to 10 cm of snow will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow of Monday represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Down to 1100 m snow will fall. The fresh snow and isolated small wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition individual gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in particular in the north. The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Moist loose snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack is not frozen and will already be soft in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of high temperatures and rain the snowpack could settle hardly at all.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. In addition individual gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in particular in the north. The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Moist loose snow slides require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above approximately 1100 m. The fresh snow and the wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack above approximately 1500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Mostly small avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep slopes especially above approximately 1600 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. Below approximately 1600 m a little snow is lying. At high altitude the avalanche danger is a little higher.
